title.value: Goal-conditioned GFlowNets for Controllable Multi-Objective Molecular Design
title.justification: The title is explicitly mentioned in the provided text.
title.quote: Goal-conditioned GFlowNets for Controllable Multi-Objective Molecular Design

extractions.description: This paper proposes the use of goal-conditioned GFlowNets to tackle the multi-objective molecular design problem, enabling more fine-grained control over trade-offs. By conditioning the Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets) on specific goal regions in the objective space, the approach aims to achieve a more comprehensive and evenly distributed Pareto front of solutions, addressing issues present in previously scalarized single-objective models.

type.justification: The paper includes experimental results, evaluation metrics, and performance comparisons for different GFlowNet conditioning strategies in the context of molecular design.
type.quote: We primarily experiment on a two-objective task, the well-known drug-likeness heuristic QED...

name.justification: The paper focuses on applying machine learning techniques for the design of chemical molecules with pharmaceutical applications.
name.quote: In recent years, in-silico molecular design has received much attention from the machine learning community.

name.justification: GFlowNets, a type of generative model, are a key component of the proposed method.
name.quote: The Generative Flow Network (GFlowNet, GFN) framework is a recently introduced method to train energy-based generative models.

name.justification: The approach takes inspiration from goal-conditional reinforcement learning and applies it to GFlowNets.
name.quote: Through the choice of distribution over these goals, we enable users of these models to have more fine-grained control over trade-offs. We also find that assuming proper coverage of the goal distribution, goal-conditioned models discover a more complete and higher entropy approximation of the Pareto front for various shapes.

name.justification: The GFlowNet framework is heavily utilized and adapted in this paper for goal-conditioned multi-objective molecular design.
name.quote: The Generative Flow Network (GFlowNet, GFN) framework is a recently introduced method to train energy-based generative models.

is_contributed.justification: The paper introduces a new adaptation of the GFlowNet specifically for goal-conditioned molecular design.
is_contributed.quote: To tackle this problem, we propose to train models which explicitly target specific regions in objective space. Taking inspiration from goal-conditional reinforcement learning (Schaul et al., 2015), we condition GFlowNet (Bengio et al., 2021a;b) models on a description of such goal regions.

is_executed.justification: Given the complexity and nature of the GFlowNet models, execution on GPUs is assumed for efficient computation.
is_executed.quote: Not explicitly stated in the paper, but considering the nature of GFlowNets and the computational intensity of the tasks, GPU execution is implied.

is_compared.justification: The paper includes comparative results between the goal-conditioned GFlowNet and other models.
is_compared.quote: Finally, to report on the controllability of the compared methods, we measure the Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) between the conditional vector c (goal or preference) and the resulting reward vector...

referenced_paper_title.value: Flow Network based Generative Models for Non-Iterative Diverse Candidate Generation
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for the GFlowNet model is cited within the text.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Generative Flow Network (GFlowNet, GFN) framework is a recently introduced method to train energy-based generative models (i.e. models that learn pθ (x) ∝ R(x); Bengio et al., 2021a).

name.justification: The well-known QED drug-likeness heuristic is used as part of the evaluation tasks.
name.quote: We primarily experiment on a two-objective task, the well-known drug-likeness heuristic QED (Bickerton et al., 2012).

referenced_paper_title.value: Quantifying the chemical beauty of drugs
referenced_paper_title.justification: This is the referenced paper for the QED drug-likeness heuristic dataset.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We primarily experiment on a two-objective task, the well-known drug-likeness heuristic QED (Bickerton et al., 2012).
